VOL. XXIV, NO. 4.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 4, 1919.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

HOPKINS TO HAVE DORMITORY

BIG PROGRESS ON HULLABALOO

HOPKINS SWAMPS LEBANON

PLAY WELL UNDER WAY

Campaign Well Under Way—$59,000
Already Pledged—A Dormitory an
Imperative Necessity.

Work on 1920 Year Book Well Begun.
Subscription Campaign Successful.
Senior Write-ups Assigned.

Calkins Shows Up Well—Tome Knocked
Out in Second Quarter—Visitors
Score by Fluke.

Rehearsals Well Attended—Scenery to
be Painted by Mr. Sachs, Assisted
by Two Hopkins Students.

Work on the Hullabaloo is progressing in fine style. Those who
have atteuded recent meetings of
the board and staff have come
away delighted with the ideas that
are being worked out to make the
1920 book the best one ever published in the history of Johns
Hopkins. Editor-in-Chief Millard
Foard has assigned the senior
writeups to members of the class
who are working out some novel
and attractive way to tell Hullabaloo readers the "inside dope"
on the personality and character
of our seniors.
The campaign for subscriptions
was started just a week ago today and so far is successful, but
there are many undergraduates
who have not taken advantage of
their opportunity to subscribe.
Signing the contract now means
no immediate expense• the $3.00
'any time
involved may be paid
before February 1.
The Hullabaloo is'not a record
of the Senior Class; it is a college annual, published by members
of the Senior Class, assisted by
the other classes, that records in
detail, by means of writeups,
drawings and a large number of
photographs, every attractive feature of college life. Every student must be interested in some
phase of the book and should subscribe not only because he is personally interested, but because it
is his duty to support every Hopkins activity.
Warren M. Driver, Jr., business
manager, emphasizes the fact that
the Hullabaloo is the best way
a student has of showing his
friends And relatives what kind
of a college Hopkins is. No one
can convey by means of words
the impression of our college that
the Hullabaloo, with its hundreds
of photographs, artistic drawings
and "snappy" writeups, presents.

Although
ten
pounds to the man, the Black and
Blue out-played the Lebanon College gridders in every department
of the game last Saturday, winThe score does not
ning, 20-6. '
show the relative worth of the
t WO teams, as it rained throughout the game, making the field
a sea of mud, and the Pennsylvanians got all the breaks of the
game. The Hopkins line played
like all-American material, throwing their heavier opponents for
losses time -and again. Lebanon
College was able to earn but one
first down to the twenty-five
which the local team tore off.
Calkins, in the backfield, played
the game of his life, bucking the
line for gains varying from five to
thirty yards repeatedly. Puss
Watson in the beginning bore the
brunt of the gaining, but tired as
the game wore on, so Calkins
came more and more into the
limelight. However, Puss showed
that he had • always one more
good punch left when he tore
around right end for a spectacular twenty-five yard run in the
fourth period, which was largely
instrumental in the scoring of the
final touchdown. Little Dick
Tome, until he was hurt, played a
brilliant game, and Bobby Owings, who went in in his place,
generaled the team cleverly.
The visitors scored their single
touchdown when Behman punted
from his 40-yard line. Tome
fumbled and Fishburn fell on the
ball behind Hopkins' goal line.
The outcome of the game was
never in doubt from the outset.
Renn kicked off to Egerton, who
was downed on the fifty yard line.
Then began a march down the
field. The Blue and White tightened on their 10-yard line and
Hoffman was sent in to dropkick. However, the angle was too
great, and the ball went wide.
Lebanon was unable to gain, and
was forced to punt. Tome ran
the ball back twenty yards, being
downed on their 40-yard line.
Hopkins tore off two more first
downs, to,be held on the visitors
15-yard line. Behman punted and
Tome fumbled. Renn recovered
the ball on ,their 40-yard line.
Again they were forced to punt,
and Landy recovered the ball on
their 45-yard line just as the
quarter ended.
The breathing spell helped the
Black and Blue, and in nine plays
the ball rested behind Lebanon's

With less than two months left
in which to complete preparations
for the presentation of Sir James
Barrie's comedy "The Admirable
Crichton," the Johns Hopkins
Dramatic Club is hard at work.
.Owing to the marked success
with which the club produced
Bernard Shaw's "You Never Can
Tell" last year, considerable interest in dramatics was displayed
at the University this fall and
about fifty men answered the call
for candidates for the cast. Under the supervision of Miss Clementine Walter as director and
chairman of the "cut" committee,
these men were given try-outs
with the result that the following have finally been selected to
fill the liositions of the cast:

(Continued on page 7, col. I)

Hopkins men will not have to
live in boarding houses next year
as is the case with many of us
now, if the enthusiasm with
which the Alumni are getting be.hind the memorial dormitory campaign - may be taken as a criterion. Beginning Monday, November 3rd, the drive will extend over
a period of four weeks, culminat- •
ing the Monday after the St.
Johu's game. Each week during
this month, a circular or folder
Will be mailed to each alumnus,
together with a form of pledge,
urging the imperative necessity of
a dormitory at Hopkins. Five
years will be allowed for the redemptioii. of this pledge. Mr.
George L. Radcliffe, Maryland's
secretary of state, is president of
the Alumni Association and is in
Charge of the campaign. The estimated cost of the dormitory will
be $300,000. The proposed new
building will be in the rear of the
Carroll mansion and will face
' Charles street. If the fund is
raised, ground will probably be
broke11 this spring and the building completed before the opening
of the University next fall. The
Plans have already been drawn.
The plan to build a memorial
dormitory came into being at the
Alumni Reunion in June, when
Mr. Glassie '92 made a stirring
appeal for "a living memorial to
What Hopkins men fought for and
died for during the war." It was
.then that the proposed campaign
became a reality, for Dr. Tom
Brown, president of the class of
1902, pledged his class for $5,000.
He was .followed by the presidents of '00 and '03 both of whom
Pledged a minimum of $10,000 for
their classes. This movement was
taken up by others until the evening ended with $59,000 pledged.
The presidents of all the Alumni
Classes have written to their
class mates in behalf of the dormitory, and prominent alumni of
Baltimore will address the Alumni Associations of the different
states. In this way the campaign
is to be brought to the attention
of every alumnus.
In the endowment campaign of
1910 six lines of expansion were
Planned.. They were: (1.) school
of higher engineering; (2.) a law
school of high grade; (3.) a training school for teachers; (4.) a department of preventive medicine;
(5.) a building of pathology,, including hygiene and bacteriology;
(6.) an extended collegiate department. In nine years since

The influx of students to Cambridge University and some other
English colleges has become so
large that it is difficult to find
lodging for all of them. Some
have had to secure rooms miles
from the college and even these
accommodations are getting surprisingly rare.
One of the novel features of
the Situation is the number of
married undergraduate students
who in some cases require a home
for a wife and children.

Realizing the large amount of
work to be done and the rather
limited time in which to do it,
the men chosen for the cast are
taking up the task before them
with the utmost enthusiasm. Rehearsals are being held in the attic of the Barn three times a
week, and in order to stimulate
better attendance a fine of one
dollar is imposed. upon absentees,
who fail to offer a satisfactory
explanation for their delinquency.
Many of the positions on the cast,
especially those involving the portrayal of feminine characters require very skillful acting, but under the guiding hand of Miss
Walter, members of the club are
rapidly developing into finished
actors fully capable of their
parts.
The Dramatic Club has taken a
great step forward by purchasing
their own stage settings instead of
borrowing them as they did last
year. The scenery is to be painted by Mr. Carol Sachs assisted by
two Hopkins students, Fulton
Lesser and Badillo. MI:. Sachs
was formerly an instruCtor in the
Commercial Art- Department of
the Maryland Institute.

BALTIMORE

The training of the combined
Musical Clubs is now well under
way. The first concert is to take
place at an early date, although
the details have not been divulged.
Trips have been arranged to five
or six points in the state, besides
our own big McCoy Hall concert
and those to be given at the various "prep" schools of the city.
The Glee Club, under the direction of Mr. Harry Hartman, has
been learning a new piece every
rehearsal — some of the finest
glee club music ever obtained. Opportunity was given last week for
the members to try their hands
at quartet work, much promising
material being found by that
method. The club has so far
found four first tenors, which is
the best luck that has been encountered for some time.
The Instrumental Club has a
wonderful assortment of mandolins, guitars, ukeleles and banjoukes. A large selection of music
is being embraced. At the last
meeting the star Hawaiian trio,
consisting of Coulter, banjo-uke,
Riggs, guitar, and Hambleton,
steel guitar, demonstrated a little
of its own high-quality jazz.
By the new system of finances
introduced by Treasurer Defandorf, absences and lateness will be
fined, and profits that are to be
divided at the end of the season
are to be figured on the basis of
the portions of the three-dollar
shares that remain after deducting these fines. Another novel
arrangement is that of allowing
men to belong to both the Glee
and Instrumental clubs by spending part time at the practices of
each. Although the membership
has become very large, opportunity for joining is still being given.
First tenors especially are in demand.

BALTIMORE, MD.,

NOV. 4, 1919

Boost the Dormitory.

The interest of Hopkins is centered on the drive, which opened
this Monday, for funds to erect a
dormitory at Homewood. It is the
real beginning of an important
era for this University. Every
one who has watched the progress
of Hopkins in the last four years,
who has seen her move from Howard street to Homewood, who has
watched the erection of the beautiful new buildings and the improvements in the grounds, must
feel pleasure in these outward
signs of inward greatness. But,
if they hold the future of Hopkins
dear, they have looked forward to
the erection of a new dormitory.
They have seen the need for housing the students of the college, for
bringing them together on the
campus in a unified community
from which can spring true col,
lege spirit.
This is what Hopkins needs
more than additions to her faculty, more than a scientific discovery, more than a treatise on some
learned subject, more than a laboratory, more than new books.
She needs a physical means to
bind her devotees together, to
"collegify" college.
This first dorinitory is to be a
memorial dormitory and its halls
are to be named after the Hopkins men who fell in the war. In
no other way could the memory
of these fallen heroes be more indelibly impressed upon the minds
of future Hopkins students. No
more fitting way in which to
honor their memory could be
found, no better tribute paid.

Such is the legend borne on
the lapels of some of the freshmen; such a tag proclaims to the
world the naked facts. Nothing
could be more appropriate than
the famous words of Jeff: "For
the love of Mike, Mutt, use discretion !"
We should be proud of this
year's Student Council. Dispossessing itself of its former whiskers and shaking to the four
winds the dust of ages, it has
shouldered its way to the front.
The freshmen are being brought
to life: witness the long line of
delinquents pleading before the
bar of justice on Mondays. The
upper classes are being brought
face to face with the fact that
they themselves are not spotless
in their attendance and support.
Soon students will no more conceive of missing a football game
than of failing to see the "Follies" on its annual visit to our
city.
But We were speaking of tags,
were we not? The one above is
purely negative in its purpose,
calling attention to something not
done. We recall printing a note
in these columns about the University of Pennsylvania activity
button, to be worn by each freshman who is "participating in any
college activity or who is working
his way through college." This is
a splendid scheme for inducing the
freshmen to find his place in the
vast machine of student activities,
and is positive in its effect. We
respectfully submit it to the attention of the Student Council.
CHESS CLUB ORGANIZES
WITH SEVENTEEN MEMBERS

At the meeting of the Chess
Club, it was decided that the
tournaments would start next
week. These tournaments will be
held for the purpose of selecting
a team and are sure to be very
interesting, as the club has some
very clever players. When the
team has been properly selected,
they will play some of the colleges that indulge in chess as a
regular sport. In fact, the club
wishes to make chess a regular
sport here and urges all men who
have only a slight knowledge of
the game to join. Those who
wish .to are requested to put a
note stating the fact in Box 672
addressed to J. Zubin.
The club announces that there
are no special hours to play in,
but that members can meet when
ever it suits them best.
The outlook of the club is of
the best with an enrollment of 17,
which it is hoped will increase.
The officers have not yet been
elected in the hope that more men
will join.

then, four of these goals have

time it is the sixth goal that is

It is believed that a dormitory
will give to Hopkins what it has
always lacked: a community
spirit. The dormitory would be a
common meeting place for all the
members of the University. It
would be the home of the faculty, graduates and undergraduates alike. An advantage of a
dormitory over other buildings, is
that it is self-supporting. The
halls would be named for Hopkins men who were killed in the
war. Former President Gilman in
his book entitled, "The Launching
of a University," said: "Nothing,
however, has happened in our history of greater importance to the
college than the move to Homewood. Here is an opportunity for
another experiinent, under most
favorable conditions. The present attractive surroundings must
react upon the student body and
lead to a happier and more satisfactory life. We who saw the beginning and watched over the infant, rejoice in the strong growing college." The dormitory presents an opportunity to bring
"college life" to Hopkins to an
extent it has never before enjoyed.

AT OTHER COLLEGES.
Dartmouth is starting on her
151st year with an enrollment of
practically 1500, among whom are
about 600 freshmen. All the
dormitories are filled and students have been turned away because of lack of room. The new
dormitory that is now under construction will relieve the situation
when completed.
• * *
Judging from present indications, students in the Harvard
Medical School will have a busy
time answering questions, as the
present enrollment figures show
390 students and 263 instructors.
This large teaching staff is possible according to Dr. D. S. Edthe dean of the school, by the
'
sail,
fact that 91 of the teaching staff
receive no salary at all, and the
remainder average'$200 per year.
Dr. Edsall attributes the success
of the school largely to • this fact,
as it is possible to give individual
instruction.
• * *
Enrollment of freshmen at the
University of Pennsylvania reached the vicinity of 2,000 at the
opening of college, and many
more were turned away on account of the lack of accommodations and equipment. As it is now
there is room for scarcely half of
the new men. This unusually
large class of freshmen has been
making much trouble for the
Sophomore Class, whom they outnumber 6 to 1.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 4, 1919.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

HOPKINS TO HAVE DORMITORY

BIG PROGRESS ON HULLABALOO

HOPKINS SWAMPS LEBANON

PLAY WELL UNDER WAY

Campaign Well Under Way—$59,000
Already Pledged—A Dormitory an
Imperative Necessity.

Work on 1920 Year Book Well Begun.
Subscription Campaign Successful.
Senior Write-ups Assigned.

Calkins Shows Up Well—Tome Knocked
Out in Second Quarter—Visitors
Score by Fluke.

Rehearsals Well Attended—Scenery to
be Painted by Mr. Sachs, Assisted
by Two Hopkins Students.

Work on the Hullabaloo is progressing in fine style. Those who
have atteuded recent meetings of
the board and staff have come
away delighted with the ideas that
are being worked out to make the
1920 book the best one ever published in the history of Johns
Hopkins. Editor-in-Chief Millard
Foard has assigned the senior
writeups to members of the class
who are working out some novel
and attractive way to tell Hullabaloo readers the "inside dope"
on the personality and character
of our seniors.
The campaign for subscriptions
was started just a week ago today and so far is successful, but
there are many undergraduates
who have not taken advantage of
their opportunity to subscribe.
Signing the contract now means
no immediate expense• the $3.00
'any time
involved may be paid
before February 1.
The Hullabaloo is'not a record
of the Senior Class; it is a college annual, published by members
of the Senior Class, assisted by
the other classes, that records in
detail, by means of writeups,
drawings and a large number of
photographs, every attractive feature of college life. Every student must be interested in some
phase of the book and should subscribe not only because he is personally interested, but because it
is his duty to support every Hopkins activity.
Warren M. Driver, Jr., business
manager, emphasizes the fact that
the Hullabaloo is the best way
a student has of showing his
friends And relatives what kind
of a college Hopkins is. No one
can convey by means of words
the impression of our college that
the Hullabaloo, with its hundreds
of photographs, artistic drawings
and "snappy" writeups, presents.

Calkins, in the backfield, played

fourth period, which was largely
instrumental in the scoring of the
final touchdown. Little Dick
Tome, until he was hurt, played a
brilliant game, and Bobby Owings, who went in in his place,
generaled the team cleverly.
The visitors scored their single
touchdown when Behman punted
from his 40-yard line. Tome
fumbled and Fishburn fell on the
ball behind Hopkins' goal line.
The outcome of the game was
never in doubt from the outset.
Renn kicked off to Egerton, who
was downed on the fifty yard line.
Then began a march down the
field. The Blue and White tightened on their 10-yard line and
Hoffman was sent in to dropkick. However, the angle was too
great, and the ball went wide.
Lebanon was unable to gain, and
was forced to punt. Tome ran
the ball back twenty yards, being
downed on their 40-yard line.
Hopkins tore off two more first
downs, to,be held on the visitors
15-yard line. Behman punted and
Tome fumbled. Renn recovered
the ball on ,their 40-yard line.
Again they were forced to punt,
and Landy recovered the ball on
their 45-yard line just as the
quarter ended.

Hopkins men will not have to
live in boarding houses next year
as is the case with many of us
now, if the enthusiasm with
which the Alumni are getting be.hind the memorial dormitory campaign - may be taken as a criterion. Beginning Monday, November 3rd, the drive will extend over
a period of four weeks, culminat- •
ing the Monday after the St.
Johu's game. Each week during
this month, a circular or folder
Will be mailed to each alumnus,
together with a form of pledge,
urging the imperative necessity of
a dormitory at Hopkins. Five
years will be allowed for the redemptioii. of this pledge. Mr.
George L. Radcliffe, Maryland's
secretary of state, is president of
the Alumni Association and is in
Charge of the campaign. The estimated cost of the dormitory will
be $300,000. The proposed new
building will be in the rear of the
Carroll mansion and will face
' Charles street. If the fund is
raised, ground will probably be
broke11 this spring and the building completed before the opening
of the University next fall. The
Plans have already been drawn.
The plan to build a memorial
dormitory came into being at the
Alumni Reunion in June, when
Mr. Glassie '92 made a stirring
appeal for "a living memorial to
What Hopkins men fought for and
died for during the war." It was
.then that the proposed campaign
became a reality, for Dr. Tom
Brown, president of the class of
1902, pledged his class for $5,000.
He was .followed by the presidents of '00 and '03 both of whom
Pledged a minimum of $10,000 for
their classes. This movement was
taken up by others until the evening ended with $59,000 pledged.
The presidents of all the Alumni
Classes have written to their
class mates in behalf of the dormitory, and prominent alumni of
Baltimore will address the Alumni Associations of the different
states. In this way the campaign
is to be brought to the attention
of every alumnus.
In the endowment campaign of
1910 six lines of expansion were
Planned.. They were: (1.) school
of higher engineering; (2.) a law
school of high grade; (3.) a training school for teachers; (4.) a department of preventive medicine;
(5.) a building of pathology,, including hygiene and bacteriology;
(6.) an extended collegiate department. In nine years since

BALTIMORE

The training of the combined
Musical Clubs is now well under
way. The first concert is to take
place at an early date, although
the details have not been divulged.
Trips have been arranged to five
or six points in the state, besides
our own big McCoy Hall concert
and those to be given at the various "prep" schools of the city.
The Glee Club, under the direction of Mr. Harry Hartman, has
been learning a new piece every
rehearsal — some of the finest
glee club music ever obtained. Opportunity was given last week for
the members to try their hands
at quartet work, much promising
material being found by that
method. The club has so far
found four first tenors, which is
the best luck that has been encountered for some time.
The Instrumental Club has a
wonderful assortment of mandolins, guitars, ukeleles and banjoukes. A large selection of music
is being embraced. At the last
meeting the star Hawaiian trio,
consisting of Coulter, banjo-uke,
Riggs, guitar, and Hambleton,
steel guitar, demonstrated a little
of its own high-quality jazz.
By the new system of finances
introduced by Treasurer Defandorf, absences and lateness will be
fined, and profits that are to be
divided at the end of the season
are to be figured on the basis of
the portions of the three-dollar
shares that remain after deducting these fines. Another novel
arrangement is that of allowing
men to belong to both the Glee
and Instrumental clubs by spending part time at the practices of
each. Although the membership
has become very large, opportunity for joining is still being given.
First tenors especially are in demand.

BALTIMORE, MD.,

NOV. 4, 1919

Boost the Dormitory.

The interest of Hopkins is centered on the drive, which opened
this Monday, for funds to erect a
dormitory at Homewood. It is the
real beginning of an important
era for this University. Every
one who has watched the progress
of Hopkins in the last four years,
who has seen her move from Howard street to Homewood, who has
watched the erection of the beautiful new buildings and the improvements in the grounds, must
feel pleasure in these outward
signs of inward greatness. But,
if they hold the future of Hopkins
dear, they have looked forward to
the erection of a new dormitory.
They have seen the need for housing the students of the college, for
bringing them together on the
campus in a unified community
from which can spring true col,
lege spirit.
This is what Hopkins needs
more than additions to her faculty, more than a scientific discovery, more than a treatise on some
learned subject, more than a laboratory, more than new books.
She needs a physical means to
bind her devotees together, to
"collegify" college.
This first dorinitory is to be a
memorial dormitory and its halls
are to be named after the Hopkins men who fell in the war. In
no other way could the memory
of these fallen heroes be more indelibly impressed upon the minds
of future Hopkins students. No
more fitting way in which to
honor their memory could be
found, no better tribute paid.

We should be proud of this
year's Student Council. Dispossessing itself of its former whiskers and shaking to the four
winds the dust of ages, it has
shouldered its way to the front.
The freshmen are being brought
to life: witness the long line of
delinquents pleading before the
bar of justice on Mondays. The
upper classes are being brought
face to face with the fact that
they themselves are not spotless
in their attendance and support.
Soon students will no more conceive of missing a football game
than of failing to see the "Follies" on its annual visit to our
city.
But We were speaking of tags,
were we not? The one above is
purely negative in its purpose,
calling attention to something not
done. We recall printing a note
in these columns about the University of Pennsylvania activity
button, to be worn by each freshman who is "participating in any
college activity or who is working
his way through college." This is
a splendid scheme for inducing the
freshmen to find his place in the
vast machine of student activities,
and is positive in its effect. We
respectfully submit it to the attention of the Student Council.
CHESS CLUB ORGANIZES

At the meeting of the Chess
Club, it was decided that the
tournaments would start next
week. These tournaments will be
held for the purpose of selecting
a team and are sure to be very
interesting, as the club has some
very clever players. When the
team has been properly selected,
they will play some of the colleges that indulge in chess as a
regular sport. In fact, the club
wishes to make chess a regular
sport here and urges all men who
have only a slight knowledge of
the game to join. Those who
wish .to are requested to put a
note stating the fact in Box 672
addressed to J. Zubin.
The club announces that there
are no special hours to play in,
but that members can meet when
ever it suits them best.
The outlook of the club is of
the best with an enrollment of 17,
which it is hoped will increase.
The officers have not yet been
elected in the hope that more men
will join.

(Continuedfrom page 1)
then, four of these goals have
been definitely reached. This
time it is the sixth goal that is
undertaken.
It is believed that a dormitory
will give to Hopkins what it has
always lacked: a community
spirit. The dormitory would be a
common meeting place for all the
members of the University. It
would be the home of the faculty, graduates and undergraduates alike. An advantage of a
dormitory over other buildings, is
that it is self-supporting. The
halls would be named for Hopkins men who were killed in the
war. Former President Gilman in
his book entitled, "The Launching
of a University," said: "Nothing,
however, has happened in our history of greater importance to the
college than the move to Homewood. Here is an opportunity for
another experiinent, under most
favorable conditions. The present attractive surroundings must
react upon the student body and
lead to a happier and more satisfactory life. We who saw the beginning and watched over the infant, rejoice in the strong growing college." The dormitory presents an opportunity to bring
"college life" to Hopkins to an
extent it has never before enjoyed.

AT OTHER COLLEGES.
Dartmouth is starting on her
151st year with an enrollment of
practically 1500, among whom are
about 600 freshmen. All the
dormitories are filled and students have been turned away because of lack of room. The new
dormitory that is now under construction will relieve the situation
when completed.
• * *
Judging from present indications, students in the Harvard
Medical School will have a busy
time answering questions, as the
present enrollment figures show
390 students and 263 instructors.
This large teaching staff is possible according to Dr. D. S. Edthe dean of the school, by the
'
sail,
fact that 91 of the teaching staff
receive no salary at all, and the
remainder average'$200 per year.
Dr. Edsall attributes the success
of the school largely to • this fact,
as it is possible to give individual
instruction.
• * *
Enrollment of freshmen at the
University of Pennsylvania reached the vicinity of 2,000 at the
opening of college, and many
more were turned away on account of the lack of accommodations and equipment. As it is now
there is room for scarcely half of
the new men. This unusually
large class of freshmen has been
making much trouble for the
Sophomore Class, whom they outnumber 6 to 1.
